### What are Linting errors?
The Python Linter is a command line program that checks your Python programs against rules that a team has already come to on writing good and elegant Python code.

### Linting Errors:
All linting errors can be classified into the following categories:

### 1. Syntax errors
Python allows you some liberties but also follows its own grammar. Anything that doesn't meet the requirements of these grammar rules is a syntax error. So Python's syntax errors fall into:

* Undefined variables
* Invalid expression
* Invalid assignment
* Invalid assignments

```python
# python lint command
$ python -m pylint --disable-disallowed-name-paterns <filename>.py
```

### 3. Missing or empty line
It is acceptable to have 1 (ONE!!!) blank line between the module or class header and the body of the code but it is strictly prohibited to have MORE THEN (1) blank line.

```python
foo = 3

bar = 5

baz = 7
```
> This code is perfectly fine and makes perfect sense. Even though blank lines are generally considered harmless and not necessary to your code, they may cause problems if you're working on code with other people. Because nobody wants to work with any form of code without blank lines. Having a single blank line that breaks the code up is fine, but if the first line of your code is empty you've already violated this rule. The Linter, therefore, will flag this

### Instructions:Write a method named'reversemap' that reverses key to value pairings. Implement the method in such a way that it accepts and returns values of any type. Below the method are a number of test cases to show how to use the method. Test with the input and the expected outputs. The expected outputs must match the original value, just not the same way.

### Method:
 public static Map<Object, Object> reversemap(Collection input, Collection expected) { if (expected == input) { return input; } Map<Object, Object, Comparator> map = new LinkedHashMap<Object, Object, Integer>(); map.put(0, expected.iterator().next(), 1); expected = new HashSet<Object>(); for(Iterator<?> i = expected.iterator(); i.hasNext();) { Object o = i.next(); if (input.contains(o)) { i.remove(); set(o, input.size(), map, 2); } } return map.get(1); }

            handle.close()

            counter +=1

    except IOError:

        print('You might need to close all other tabs')

### Demo (You want to make sure you can solve this yourself!)

[You can test it at codility](https://app.codility.com/programmers/lessons/5-strings/string_search/).
### Example solution

```python
class Solution(object):
    def strstr(self, str, needle, haystack):
      """
      :type str: str
      :type needle: str
      :rtype: bool
      """
      start, end = 0, len(haystack)
      while start < end:
        mid = (start + end) // 2
        if haystack [mid] not in needle:
          start = mid-1
        else:
          if haystack [mid + 1:] in needle:
            end = mid
          else:
            return True
      return False  
```
